Pulls the 357 Ruger from his pocket with a handkerchief and places it in the oil can to presumably clean or hide it.
Hesitates at the door and looks back towards the oil can just before the squad car arrives, indicating awareness but failure to completely avoid being caught.
Is too late to prevent police from entering and finding the gun; fails to secure evidence before arrival of squad car.
Acknowledges Ellie's valid point about the shell casing not matching the murder weapon and confirms it is legitimate.
Dismisses further investigation by firmly stating the case is closed despite the new evidence suggesting otherwise.
Confidently informs Walter that Randy Stetz is in jail, indicating knowledge and control of the situation.
Refuses to talk further despite Walter's attempt to collaborate, showing decisiveness.
Losess temper and resorts to physical aggression against Walter, indicating poor emotional control.
Expresses anger and frustration, with bloodshot eyes, potentially impairing his judgment.
Acknowledges and gives credit to others by saying he had a lot of help from Nightmute's finest.
Appears uncomfortable receiving praise and does not openly express gratitude, nods towards Fred instead.
Engages politely and does not reject Ellie’s friendly gesture; allows a hug and appreciates her support.
Despite severe injury and losing blood fast, Will carefully approaches the boathouse, noting Walter's lack of hearing aid and uses this advantage to sneak up behind him undetected.
Admits to shooting Detective Eckhart and covering it up, acknowledging his mistake and warning Ellie not to lose her way.
Allows Ellie to take control of his wound treatment despite his fading condition, showing some acceptance of his vulnerability.
Asks Ellie to let him sleep (implying he wants to give up), showing a moment of weakness and loss of will to fight.
